What is metadata?

Metadata is information you can add to a DITA map (or a topic) that gives more information about the content. By correctly creating and applying metadata, you can make it easier to search through information which is relevant to your company or organization. This way, you can add digital identifying criteria to your documents, which help you organize your resources in a digital information architecture. As it is generally information that is more useful to the author than to the reader, the reader does not get to see it. Metadata can include information such as creation date, author, semantics of the textual components, and copyright ownership.

Data vs. metadata

An important distinction should be made between data and metadata. Data is synonymous with content, so the information you write in your topics will be data. Metadata, on the other hand, is information about the content, such as the name of the author, when the files were created, who the copyright holder is etc.

This distinction becomes important when you look at the types of files you will use in DITA. Topics can contain content but DITA maps should never contain content. As such, topics can have data as well as metadata, whereas DITA maps should only ever have metadata.

Overriding metadata

You can create metadata in both topics and maps. The metadata in a topic applies to all the elements within the entire topic. Similarly, the metadata of a DITA map applies to the entire map. As such, it will override the metadata of its topics.

There are ways to prevent this and ensure the metadata in a topic takes precedence. You can, for instance, adjust the @lockmeta attribute on the <topicmeta> element to control whether map-specified values override values in the referenced topic.

Types of topic metadata

Metadata of documents are not set in stone. As the owner of a document, you can add and delete metadata as you wish. But it is essential, when saving documents in an organization or company, that there is one administrator who created well-thought-out rules.

Type Purpose
<critdates> Contains the creation and revising date of the topic or map.
<author> Contains the name and other information of the topic's author.
<copyright> Contains the year (<copyryear>) and the owner of the copyright (<copyrholder>)
<prodinfo> Contains the product name, version, release date, brand, series, platform etc.
If youâ€™re working in Photoshop, Lightroom or other graphic editors, it is not uncommon to add metadata that apply to the size of the picture or the location where the picture was taken.
  • How large is the picture?
  • Which colors are being used?
  • Where has the picture been taken?
But you can even go further: Which mood does this picture provoke? The possibilities with metadata are infinite.

International standards for metadata

The possibilities may be endless, but they are bound by international standards. The most important of these are the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) and the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). The most exalted metadata standard is ISO/IEC 11179 Metadata Registries (MDR).
